heading: Soil Spectroscopy for Global Good
text:
SoilSpec4GG USDA-funded Food Agriculture Cyberinformatics
Tools Coordinated Innovation Network NIFA Award #2020-67021-32467 project. brings together soil
scientists, spectroscopists, informaticians, data scientists 
software engineers overcome current bottlenecks
preventing wider efficient use soil spectroscopy. series
working groups formed address topics including calibration
transfer, model choice, outreach & demonstration, use 
spectroscopy inform global carbon cycle modeling. info refer
: https://soilspectroscopy.org/.R tutorials software developed implement OSSL available via: https://github.com/soilspectroscopy.Soil spectroscopy global good project works global initiatives including FAO Global Soil Partnership IEEE P4005 Standards Protocols Soil Spectroscopy Working Group.

heading: What is soil spectroscopy?
text:
Soil spectroscopy measurement light absorption light visible, near infrared mid infrared (Vis–NIR–MIR) regions electromagnetic spectrum applied soil surface. proportion incident radiation reflected soil sensed Vis–NIR–MIR reflectance spectroscopy. characteristic spectra (see Fig. ) can used estimate numerous soil attributes including: particle size distribution, mineral organic compounds, water.
Figure 0.1: Schematic explanation soil spectroscopy. info see: https://soilspectroscopy.org/.

heading: Open Soil Spectral Library
text: Open Soil Spectral Library (OSSL) suite datasets, web-services, software, tutorials. includes (see also https://github.com/soilspectroscopy):soil spectral database shared several formats (mongoDB, cloud bucket, API);API database access prediction service available https://api.soilspectroscopy.org;Front-end solutions: OSSL Engine OSSL Explorer;Registry global local prediction models (https://github.com/soilspectroscopy/);Tutorials included book.MIR spectral diversityMIR locationsVisNIR locations

heading: Importing new datasets to OSSL
text: OSSL database prepared following OSSL schema available ossl-imports.github repository ossl-imports importing codes preparing integrating new datasets OSSL. folder ossl-imports/dataset contains datasets separated name/code, internal README.Rmd file describing detail steps necessary preparing standardizing files OSSL format.original files placed internal server avoid storage big files github repository, can found persistent online repositories public license. original datasets public license shared project restrictions shared publicly. keep original files local repository run importing notebooks (ossl-imports/dataset/../README.Rmd), operation can run internal server.New contributors encouraged host files public repository draft importing step github pull requests. final checks consolidation, however, concluded internal server.README.Rmd files follow basic structure. one description dataset top notebook links dataset source references. extended description provided book.preparing import, following subsections defined:Basic description.Soil site information.Soil laboratory (wet chemistry) dataMid-infrared (MIR) spectroscopy data (optional).Visible-near-infrared (VisNIR) spectroscopy data (optional).Quality control.References.subsection reading processing functions, outputs can joined using shared id columns. output files share name pattern can retrieved different folder names, binded together final stage. outputs named ossl_soilsite_<version>.qs, ossl_soillab_<version>.qs, ossl_mir_<version>.qs, ossl_visnir_<version>.qs. version number adjusted recurring updates.

heading: 2.1.9 SERBIA.SSL
text: Description: Serbian SSL dataset 135 samples shared University Novi Sad published Jović, Ćirić, Kovačević, Šeremešić, & Kordić (2019). soil samples sampled 2009. Samples taken three different types soil: arable, meadow, forest, 3 different depths: 0-30 cm, 30-60 cm 60-90 cm location (n=45). Classical wet chemistry analyses includes texture, carbon total, carbon organic, carbon inorganic, pH, C/N ratio, CaCO3. texture complete data depths, soil properties determined 0-30 cm layer. spectra MIR range taken depths using ThermoFisher Nicolet Nexus 670 DTGS detector, diffuse reflectance module, gold background reference. MIR spectra obtained spectral range 400-4000 cm-1 duplicates. coordinates sampling sites given lower precision.📕 Jovića, B., Ćirićb, V., Kovačevića, M., Šeremešićb, S., Kordića, B. (2019). Empirical equation preliminary assessment soil texture. Spectrochimica Acta Part : Molecular Biomolecular Spectroscopy (Vol. 206, p. 506-511). https://doi.org/10.1016/j.saa.2018.08.039.🔗 Project website: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.saa.2018.08.039©️ Data license: CC-4.0📍 Unique locations: 45📋 Unique complete scans: 135📝 Import steps: Serbia

heading: 3 OSSL database description
text: reading work--progress SoilSpec4GG manual. chapter currently draft version, peer-review publication pending.following subsections provide OSSL variable names, types, description, example. can also find information tabular format:OSSL soil site data.OSSL soil lab data (level 0).OSSL soil lab data (level 1).OSSL soil MIR data.OSSL soil VisNIR data.

heading: 3.1.1 dataset.code_ascii_txt
text: 📚 Description: OSSL dataset code.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: AFSIS1.SSL.

heading: 3.1.2 id.layer_uuid_txt
text: 📚 Description: OSSL unique identifier.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: ded584d70bf0474202d30e575ae24784.

heading: 3.1.3 id.layer_local_c
text: 📚 Description: Original observation identifier.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: icr072246.

heading: 3.1.4 longitude.point_wgs84_dd
text: 📚 Description: Longitude decimal degrees (WGS84, EPSG 4326).🔢 Type: numeric.📖 Example: 15.6874916700.

heading: 3.1.5 latitude.point_wgs84_dd
text: 📚 Description: Latitude decimal degrees (WGS84, EPSG 4326).🔢 Type: numeric.📖 Example: -7.37775000.

heading: 3.1.6 layer.sequence_usda_uint16
text: 📚 Description: Layer sequence (incremented depth).🔢 Type: numeric.📖 Example: 1.

heading: 3.1.7 layer.upper.depth_usda_cm
text: 📚 Description: Layer top depth cm.🔢 Type: numeric.📖 Example: 0.0.

heading: 3.1.8 layer.lower.depth_usda_cm
text: 📚 Description: Layer bottom depth cm.🔢 Type: numeric.📖 Example: 20.0.

heading: 3.1.9 observation.date.begin_iso.8601_yyyy.mm.dd
text: 📚 Description: Begin date observation following YYYY-MM-DD format (ISO 8601).🔢 Type: numeric.📖 Example: 2011-01-01.

heading: 3.1.10 observation.date.end_iso.8601_yyyy.mm.dd
text: 📚 Description: End date observation following YYYY-MM-DD format (ISO 8601).🔢 Type: numeric.📖 Example: 2013-12-31.

heading: 3.1.11 surveyor.title_utf8_txt
text: 📚 Description: Field surveyor name organization.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: L.T.Desta.

heading: 3.1.12 id.project_ascii_txt
text: 📚 Description: Project name.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: Africa Soil Information Service (AfSIS-1).

heading: 3.1.13 id.location_olc_txt
text: 📚 Description: Unique Open Location Code precision 6 decimal places point coordinates.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: 6F4QJMCP+VX.

heading: 3.1.14 layer.texture_usda_txt
text: 📚 Description: Texture description based USDA classification.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: sand.

heading: 3.1.15 pedon.taxa_usda_txt
text: 📚 Description: Soil classification based USDA Keys Soil Taxonomy.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: Typic Kanhaplustalf.

heading: 3.1.16 horizon.designation_usda_txt
text: 📚 Description: Soil horizon based USDA Keys Soil Taxonomy.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: Ap.

heading: 3.1.17 longitude.county_wgs84_dd
text: 📚 Description: County centroid, longitude decimal degrees (WGS84, EPSG 4326).🔢 Type: numeric.📖 Example: -96.688800.

heading: 3.1.18 latitude.county_wgs84_dd
text: 📚 Description: County centroid, latitude decimal degrees (WGS84, EPSG 4326).🔢 Type: numeric.📖 Example: 40.78446.

heading: 3.1.19 location.point.error_any_m
text: 📚 Description: Approximate point location error m.🔢 Type: numeric.📖 Example: 30.

heading: 3.1.20 location.country_iso.3166_txt
text: 📚 Description: Country code following ISO 3166.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: NZL.

heading: 3.1.21 observation.ogc.schema.title_ogc_txt
text: 📚 Description: Observation OGC schema title.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: Open Soil Spectroscopy Library.

heading: 3.1.22 observation.ogc.schema_idn_url
text: 📚 Description: Observation OGC schema url.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: https://soilspectroscopy.github.io.

heading: 3.1.23 surveyor.contact_ietf_email
text: 📚 Description: Surveyor contact email.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: afsis.info@africasoils.net.

heading: 3.1.24 surveyor.address_utf8_txt
text: 📚 Description: Surveyor institution address.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: ICRAF, PO Box 30677, Nairobi, 00100, Kenya.

heading: 3.1.25 dataset.title_utf8_txt
text: 📚 Description: Dataset name.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: Africa Soil Information Service (AfSIS-1).

heading: 3.1.26 dataset.owner_utf8_txt
text: 📚 Description: Name organization person responsible dataset.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: ICRAF, CROPNUTS, RRES.

heading: 3.1.27 dataset.address_idn_url
text: 📚 Description: URL address dataset web page.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: https://www.isric.org/explore/ISRIC-collections.

heading: 3.1.28 dataset.doi_idf_url
text: 📚 Description: Digital object identifier (DOI) url dataset.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.geodrs.2015.06.002.

heading: 3.1.29 dataset.license.title_ascii_txt
text: 📚 Description: Dataset license.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: ODC Open Database License.

heading: 3.1.30 dataset.license.address_idn_url
text: 📚 Description: Dataset license url.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: https://opendatacommons.org/licenses/odbl/.

heading: 3.1.31 dataset.contact.name_utf8_txt
text: 📚 Description: Dataset contact name.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: Keith Shepherd.

heading: 3.1.32 dataset.contact_ietf_email
text: 📚 Description: Dataset contact email.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: afsis.info@africasoils.net.

heading: 3.1.33 id.dataset.site_ascii_txt
text: 📚 Description: Site identification.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: 203.

Similarly, wavenumber (WN, cm-1) can converted wavelength (WL, nm) WN = 1/(WL*10000000), backtransform WL = 1/(WL*10000000). factor 10M used convert cm nm.

heading: 4 OSSL database access
text: reading work--progress SoilSpec4GG manual. chapter currently draft version, peer-review publication pending.OSSL distributed Google storage bucket, MongoDB, API. Google Cloud storage bucket hosts static files two formats: compressed csv (.csv.gz) qs (qs R package). csv.gz intended work across different platforms, qs preferred format used within R. MongoDB API can used construct requests fetch data specific filters (e.g. region, dataset source, etc.), differently static files need download whole database.OSSL, original dataset share common ids across VisNIR MIR range. ids, however, one range represented (either VisNIR MIR). OSSL tabular database keeping least one spectral range. filter must run using database remove observations missing spectra desired range.access extend global compilation soil legacy point data sets, refer https://github.com/OpenGeoHub/SoilSamples repository.

heading: Google Cloud Storage
text: datasets public bucket can updated without notice. One can run link browser download files, provide URLs programming language automatically fecth .Use following URLs access whole database levels:Compressed csvhttps://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/ossl_all_L0_v1.2.csv.gzhttps://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/ossl_all_L1_v1.2.csv.gzqs format (preferred R)https://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/ossl_all_L0_v1.2.qshttps://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/ossl_all_L1_v1.2.qsUse alternative URLs access OSSL separate files:Compressed csvhttps://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/ossl_soilsite_L0_v1.2.csv.gzhttps://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/ossl_soillab_L0_v1.2.csv.gzhttps://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/ossl_soillab_L1_v1.2.csv.gzhttps://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/ossl_mir_L0_v1.2.csv.gzhttps://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/ossl_visnir_L0_v1.2.csv.gzqs format (preferred R)https://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/ossl_soilsite_L0_v1.2.qshttps://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/ossl_soillab_L0_v1.2.qshttps://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/ossl_soillab_L1_v1.2.qshttps://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/ossl_mir_L0_v1.2.qshttps://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/ossl_visnir_L0_v1.2.qsExample R. Use dataset.code_ascii_txt id.layer_uuid_txt. joining columns:
code:
## Packages
library("tidyverse")
library("curl")
library("qs")

## Separate files
soil <-  "https://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/ossl_soillab_L1_v1.2.qs"
soil <- curl_fetch_memory(soil)
soil <- qdeserialize(soil$content)
mir <- "https://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/ossl_mir_L0_v1.2.qs"
mir <- curl_fetch_memory(mir)
mir <- qdeserialize(mir$content)

## Join
ossl <- left_join(mir, soil, by = c("dataset.code_ascii_txt", "id.layer_uuid_txt"))

heading: MongoDB
text: Available collections:soilsite: site information, e.g., coordinates, pedons, layers, etc.soillab_L0: original soil laboratory data (wet chemistry), e.g., soil texture, carbon, etc.soillab_L1: harmonized soil laboratory data (wet chemistry), e.g., soil texture, carbon, etc.mir: MIR spectral data 600-4000 cm-1 range metadata.visnir: VisNIR spectral data 350-2500 nm range metadata.ossl_L0: Whole OSSL separate tables joined level 0.ossl_L1: Whole OSSL separate tables joined level 1.NOTE: Within MongoDB, dots column names replaced underscore.Accessing R:
code:
## Packages and helping functions

library(mongolite)
library(jsonify)

soilspec4gg.db = list(
  host = 'api.soilspectroscopy.org',
  name = 'soilspec4gg',
  user = 'soilspec4gg',
  pw = 'soilspec4gg'
)

soilspec4gg.db$url <- paste0(
  'mongodb://', soilspec4gg.db$user, ':', 
  soilspec4gg.db$pw, '@', 
  soilspec4gg.db$host, '/', 
  soilspec4gg.db$name, '?ssl=true'
)

soilspec4gg.init <- function() {
  print('Creating the access for mongodb collections.')
  soilspec4gg.db$collections <<- list(
    soilsite = mongo(collection = 'soilsite', url = soilspec4gg.db$url, verbose = TRUE),
    soillab_L0 = mongo(collection = 'soillab_L0', url = soilspec4gg.db$url, verbose = TRUE),
    soillab_L1 = mongo(collection = 'soillab_L1', url = soilspec4gg.db$url, verbose = TRUE),
    mir = mongo(collection = 'mir', url = soilspec4gg.db$url, verbose = TRUE),
    visnir = mongo(collection = 'visnir', url = soilspec4gg.db$url, verbose = TRUE),
    ossl_L0 = mongo(collection = 'ossl_L0', url = soilspec4gg.db$url, verbose = TRUE),
    ossl_L1 = mongo(collection = 'ossl_L1', url = soilspec4gg.db$url, verbose = TRUE)
  )  
}

## Accessing the database

# Initialization
soilspec4gg.init()

# Checking available collections
names(soilspec4gg.db$collections)

# Get all records for soilsite table
soilspec4gg.db$collections$soilsite$count("{}")

# Read all data from a collection back to the R environment
soilsite <- soilspec4gg.db$collections$soilsite$find('{}')

# Getting unique values for a field
soilspec4gg.db$collections$soilsite$distinct(key = "dataset_code_ascii_txt")

# Getting column names
names(soilspec4gg.db$collections$ossl_L0$find('{}', limit = 1))[1:20]
names(soilspec4gg.db$collections$ossl_L1$find('{}', limit = 1))[1:20]
names(soilspec4gg.db$collections$soilsite$find('{}', limit = 1))
names(soilspec4gg.db$collections$soillab_L0$find('{}', limit = 1))
names(soilspec4gg.db$collections$soillab_L1$find('{}', limit = 1))
names(soilspec4gg.db$collections$mir$find('{"dataset_code_ascii_txt": "KSSL.SSL"}', limit = 1))[1:20]
names(soilspec4gg.db$collections$visnir$find('{"dataset_code_ascii_txt": "LUCAS.SSL"}', limit = 1))[1:20]

# Query a specific dataset
soilsite.serbia <- soilspec4gg.db$collections$soilsite$find('{"dataset_code_ascii_txt" : "SERBIA.SSL"}')

# Filtering by ID
soilspec4gg.db$collections$soilsite$find('{"id_layer_uuid_txt": "50d0bfaaf50feb0ba2c8a3aa2cd788bb"}')

heading: API
text:
OSSL API (Application Programming Interface) also available can used construct requests fetch data, models generate predictions. outputs predictions can obtained JSON CSV files, making system fully interoperable. heading: 5 OSSL reference models
text:
reading work--progress SoilSpec4GG manual. chapter currently draft version, peer-review publication pending.received important feedback people said current models great job, others much. can due specific soil types well represented due spectra well aligned OSSL. plan conduct systematic analysis learning algorithms, global vs local fitting, compression methods preprocessing using OSSL database. Another great interest test including spatial covariates fusing different spectral regions really help deliver reliable predictions.following sections describe steps used produce OSSL models, 
used OSSL prediction service API. current available models
fitted using previous OSSL database version 1.0. -depth insight 
modeling steps please refer ossl-models repository.

heading: 5.1 OSSL global soil spectroscopy callibrarion models
text:
fitted number calibration models using OSSL MIR VisNIR spectra
combination additional covariates, now publicly available
use CC-license. modeling use Ensemble Machine Learning
framework implemented R mlr programming environment
following parameters:Regression first 60 Principal Component Analysis PC’s raw spectra;Four base learners: Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, Cubist Lasso Elastic-Net Regularized GLM;Ensemble Machine Learning stacking / meta-learner 5-fold Cross-Validation;Blocking using 100×100-km spatial grid avoid possible overfitting;Feature selection model-parameter fine-tuning using random sequential backward search;details models fitted refer : https://github.com/soilspectroscopy/ossl-models.standard global soil spectral calibration models use various calibration frameworks including:Using MIR spectra calibration.Using VisNIR spectra calibration.Using combination MIR VisNIR spectra.Using combination MIR VisNIR spectra + geographic covariates.methods 1 & 2 standard methods described literature (Wadoux et al., 2021). methods
3 & 4 referred “MIR-VisNIR fusion” approach (Vohland, Ludwig, Seidel, & Hutengs, 2022).
method 4 “field-specific calibration approach”; refer 
“bundle approach” basically use information available
help produce best predictions targeted soil properties.Users can choose opt one multiple calibration models, also
depends type data (VisNIR, MIR, coordinates depths known yes/) used course.
online callibration service (https://engine.soilspectroscopy.org) API
can used predicting values soil properties smaller datasets (<1000 rows).Soil spectral scans obtained different spectroscopic instruments often 
modeled analyzed together .e. require kind calibration (Lei & Sun, 2022)
one can fit cross-instrument / cross-dataset calibration models.
OSSL library thus use also instrument / dataset code indicator variable.
complex models currently OSSL , thus, one users need define :Input MIR spectra,Input VisNIR spectra (samples),Geographical location soil depth,Instrument code / dataset code;

heading: 5.2 Using default OSSL models to predict soil properties
text:
OSSL model registry (RDS) S3 file services currently includes large number 
prediction models fitted list soil properties. complete list available file OSSL_models_meta.csv.

heading: 5.2.1 Predicting soil properties using MIR spectra
text:
example, predict soil organic carbon weight percent (oc_usda.calc_wpct) using MIR spectra, need load
two models (1) principal component model mpca_mir_kssl_v1.rds,
(2) mlr model predicting oc_usda.calc_wpct:Note models (RDS files) can 10 200 MB size, depending complexity models
size training data used.Principal Component Analysis described OSSL models repository.
standard way compressing 1000+ spectral bands predictive modeling (Chang, Laird, Mausbach, & Hurburgh Jr, 2001).
use first 60 PCA components modeling, arbitrary decisions.can look summary model typing:shows model ensemble Machine Learning model based stacking 
four individual models: regr.ranger (Random Forest) (Wright & Ziegler, 2017), regr.xgboost (Gradient Boosting) (Chen et al., 2015),
regr.cvglmnet (Lasso Elastic-Net Regularized GLM) (Friedman, Hastie, & Tibshirani, 2010) regr.cubist (Cubist) (Kuhn, Weston, Keefer, & Coulter, 2012). RMSE
model 0.150 (R-square = 0.978), based 5-fold Cross Validation spatial blocking (global grid 100 km blocks).
Model based 72,246 training points.can take look accuracy plot model:
Figure 5.1: Accuracy plot log..oc_usda.calc_wpct/mir_mlr..eml_kssl_na_v1.rds.
Next, load sample MIR data can use predict soil organic carbon:simple table raw MIR spectral data (absorbances) prepared table.
column names contain wavelengths / MIR channels:can generate predictions using:ylim=c(0,100) specifies prediction values need range 0 100 (values range replaced either 0 100).
output model consists four parts:Predictions back-transformed value lower upper prediction intervals (1 std.);Data frame covariate layers needed generate predictions;Summary meta-learner predicted observed values;Ratio variance predictions produced using base learners MSE;predictions format:means predicted oc_usda.calc_wpct first row 0 etc. 
lower.1std upper.1std indicate standard prediction interval based 
prediction error derived log-space. higher values oc_usda.calc_wpct
prediction interval gets thus proportionally higher larger absolute values e.g. row 14 24% 39%:Finally, can check well new data (MIR scans) reflect training
data used build calibration models:

Near-infrared (NIR) soil spectral library using NeoSpectra Handheld NIR Analyzer Si-Ware. doi:10.5281/ZENODO.7586622.

heading: 6.1 Overview
text: Recent advances hardware technology enabled development handheld sensors similar performance specifications laboratory-grade near-infrared (NIR) spectrometers.compiled hand-held NIR spectral library (1350-2550 nm) using NeoSpectra Handheld NIR Analyzer developed Si-Ware. scanner fitted Fourier-Transform technology based semiconductor Micro Electromechanical Systems (MEMS) manufacturing technique, promising accuracy, consistency devices.library includes 2,106 distinct mineral soil samples scanned across 9 portable low-cost NIR spectrometers (indicated serial ). 2,016 soil samples selected represent diversity mineral soils found United States, 90 samples selected across Ghana, Kenya, Nigeria.519 US samples selected scanned Woodwell Climate Research Center. samples queried USDA NRCS NSSC-KSSL Soil Archives complete set eight measured properties (TC, OC, TN, CEC, pH, clay, sand, silt). stratified based major horizon taxonomic order, omitting categories less 500 samples. Three percent stratum (.e., combination major horizon taxonomic order) randomly selected final subset retrieved KSSL’s physical soil archive 2-mm sieved samples.remaining 1,604 US samples queried USDA NRCS NSSC-KSSL Soil Archives University Nebraska - Lincoln meet following criteria: Lower depth <= 30 cm, pH range 4.0 9.5, Organic carbon <10%, Greater lower detection limits, Actual physical samples available archive, Samples collected analyzed 2001 onwards, Samples complete analyses high-priority properties (Sand, Silt, Clay, CEC, Exchangeable Ca, Exchangeable Mg, Exchangeable K, Exchangeable Na, CaCO3, OC, TN), & MIR scanned.samples scanned dry 2mm sieved. ~20g sample added plastic weighing boat NeoSpectra scanner placed make direct contact soil surface. scanner gently moved across surface sample 6 replicate scans taken. replicates averaged one spectra per sample per scanner resulting database.

heading: 6.2.1 Google Cloud Bucket
text: Use following URLs access whole database levels:Compressed csvhttps://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/neospectra_soillab_v1.2.csv.gzhttps://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/neospectra_soilsite_v1.2.csv.gzhttps://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/neospectra_nir_v1.2.csv.gzhttps://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/neospectra_mir_v1.2.csv.gzqs format (preferred R)https://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/neospectra_soillab_v1.2.qshttps://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/neospectra_soilsite_v1.2.qshttps://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/neospectra_nir_v1.2.qshttps://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/neospectra_mir_v1.2.qsExample R.
code:
## Packages
library("tidyverse")
library("curl")
library("qs")

## Separate files
soil <-  "https://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/neospectra_soillab_v1.2.qs"
soil <- curl_fetch_memory(soil)
soil <- qdeserialize(soil$content)

nir <- "https://storage.googleapis.com/soilspec4gg-public/neospectra_nir_v1.2.qs"
nir <- curl_fetch_memory(nir)
nir <- qdeserialize(nir$content)

## Join
neospectra <- right_join(soil, nir, by = c("id.sample_local_c"))

heading: 6.2.2 MongoDB
text: Available collections:neospectra_soilsite: site information, e.g., coordinates, pedons, layers, etc.neospectra_soillab: soil laboratory data (wet chemistry), e.g., soil texture, carbon, etc.neospectra_nir: Near-infrared (NIR) spectral data 1350-2550 nm range metadata.neospectra_mir: Middle-infrared (MIR) spectral data 600-4000 cm-1 range metadata.NOTE: Within MongoDB, dots column names replaced underscore.Accessing R:
code:
## Packages and helping functions
library(mongolite)
library(jsonify)

soilspec4gg.db = list(
  host = 'api.soilspectroscopy.org',
  name = 'soilspec4gg',
  user = 'soilspec4gg',
  pw = 'soilspec4gg'
)

soilspec4gg.db$url <- paste0(
  'mongodb://', soilspec4gg.db$user, ':', 
  soilspec4gg.db$pw, '@', 
  soilspec4gg.db$host, '/', 
  soilspec4gg.db$name, '?ssl=true'
)

soilspec4gg.init <- function() {
  print('Creating the access for mongodb collections.')
  soilspec4gg.db$collections <<- list(
    neospectra_soilsite = mongo(collection = 'neospectra_soilsite', url = soilspec4gg.db$url, verbose = TRUE),
    neospectra_soillab = mongo(collection = 'neospectra_soillab', url = soilspec4gg.db$url, verbose = TRUE),
    neospectra_nir = mongo(collection = 'neospectra_nir', url = soilspec4gg.db$url, verbose = TRUE),
    neospectra_mir = mongo(collection = 'neospectra_mir', url = soilspec4gg.db$url, verbose = TRUE)
  ) 
}

## Accessing the database

# Initialization
soilspec4gg.init()

# Checking available collections
names(soilspec4gg.db$collections)

# Get all records for neospectra_soilsite table
soilspec4gg.db$collections$neospectra_soilsite$count("{}")

# Read all data from a collection back to the R environment
neospectra_soilsite <- soilspec4gg.db$collections$neospectra_soilsite$find('{}')

# Getting unique values for a field
soilspec4gg.db$collections$neospectra_soilsite$distinct(key = "scan_nir_model_name_utf8_txt")

# Getting column names
names(soilspec4gg.db$collections$neospectra_soilsite$find('{}', limit = 1))

heading: 6.3 Database description
text: Neospectra database follows specification OSSL soil site information. near-infrared (NIR) spectra, however, additional information provided scanning laboratory, scanner code, scanning accessory.NIR provided reflectance units per wavelength, values usually ranging 0 1 fraction percent. spectral range imported OSSL falls 1350 2550 nm, interval 2 nm.One can convert reflectance (R) values absorbance units () = log10(1/R), backtransform R = 1/(10^). Similarly, wavenumber (WN, cm-1) can converted wavelength (WL, nm) WN = 1/(WL*10000000), backtransform WL = 1/(WL*10000000). factor 10M used convert cm nm.

heading: 6.3.1 id.sample_local_c
text: 📚 Description: Soil sample identifier.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: 30747.

heading: 6.3.2 id.scan_local_c
text: 📚 Description: Scan identifier (one average spectra per scanner).🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: NEO1_030747.

heading: 6.3.3 scan.lab_utf8_txt
text: 📚 Description: Scanning laboratory.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: Woodwell.

heading: 6.3.4 scan.visnir.date.begin_iso.8601_yyyy.mm.dd
text: 📚 Description: Begin date scanning following YYYY-MM-DD format (ISO 8601).🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: 2021-01-01.

heading: 6.3.5 scan.visnir.date.end_iso.8601_yyyy.mm.dd
text: 📚 Description: Begin date scanning following YYYY-MM-DD format (ISO 8601).🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: 2022-12-31.

heading: 6.3.6 scan.nir.model.name_utf8_txt
text: 📚 Description: NIR scanner code.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: NEO1.

heading: 6.3.7 scan.nir.model.serialnumber_utf8_in
text: 📚 Description: NIR scanner serial number.🔢 Type: numeric.📖 Example: 21020033.

heading: 6.3.8 scan.nir.accessory.used_utf8_txt
text: 📚 Description: Yes scanning accesory.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: y.

heading: 6.3.9 scan.visnir.method.preparation_any_txt
text: 📚 Description: Soil sample preparation scanning.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: <2 mm.

heading: 6.3.10 scan.visnir.license.title_ascii_txt
text: 📚 Description: Dataset scans license.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: CC-.

heading: 6.3.11 scan.visnir.license.address_idn_url
text: 📚 Description: Dataset scans license url.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: https://creativecommons.org/licenses//4.0/.

heading: 6.3.12 scan.visnir.doi_idf_url
text: 📚 Description: Digital object identifier (DOI) url dataset scans.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.7586622.

heading: 6.3.13 scan.visnir.contact.name_utf8_txt
text: 📚 Description: Dataset scans contact name.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: Jonathan Sanderman.

heading: 6.3.14 scan.visnir.contact.email_ietf_txt
text: 📚 Description: Dataset scans contact email.🔢 Type: string.📖 Example: jsanderman@woodwellclimate.org.

heading: 6.3.15 scan_visnir.1350_ref
text: 📚 Description: Reflectance fraction unit, first wavelength 1350-2550 nm range.🔢 Type: numeric.📖 Example: 0.10403320.

heading: 6.3.16 scan_visnir.2550_ref
text: 📚 Description: Reflectance fraction unit, last wavelength 1350-2550 nm range.🔢 Type: numeric.📖 Example: 0.3622029.
